p.foreign: A)MBLU/THTES , I)/LIGGOI, TENO/NTWN BA/REA, FLEBW=N E)N TW=| TRAXH/LW| PLHRW/SIES KAI\ DIATA/SIES, NAUTI/A TE POLLH\ ME\N E)PI\ SITI/OIS, OU)X H(/KISTA DE\ KAI\ E)P' A)SITI/H|SI KAI\ BLHXRH/·
p.note: In all the former editions, instead of TE POLLH\, we read TA\ POLLA\ and, with the exception of that of Dr. Ermerins, all have KAI\ before BLHXRH/. The Latin translation of this clause by Wigan, Kuhn, and Ermerins, is this: "Nausea præcipué quidem post cibum, sed quæ per abstinentiam quoque lenté continuat," which is evidently very loose and vague. That of Crassus is far more strict and accurate: "Nausea frequentius quidem e cibis, non minimé tamen et ab inedia pusilla quædam nausea sequitur." The English translation of the text as it formerly stood would run thus: "Nausea for the most part, indeed, after food; but also, not unfrequently, slight nausea after abstinence." It appears to me, however, that the meaning is so much improved by the slight change I have ventured to make, that I flatter myself no argument is required to prove it to be the true reading. The contrast between POLLH\ in the one case, and BLHXRH\ in the other, is most suitable to the sense. That the repetition of KAI\ is legitimate in this clause of the sentence, will not be questioned by any one who is familiar with the style of Galen. See, for example, De Locis Affectis, v.i., prope initium; t.iii. p. 296, ed. Basil.
p.foreign: KAI\ FLE/GMA E)MEI=TAI SUXNO/N· A)POSITI/H KAI\ A)PEYI/H E)PI\ SMIKROI=SI E)DE/SMASI· FUSW/DEES, E)PHRME/NOI U(POXO/NDRIA. TA/DE ME\N OU)=N DIHNEKE/A.
*)\HN DE\ PLHSI/ON H)/DH

note.p: The common reading in the MSS. is EI)/DEOS, which is evidently inadmissible. Petit, in his Commentary, suggests that the true reading is DE/OS H(|. Wigan also prefers PLHSI/ON EI)/H DE/OS. Ermerins accordingly reads PLHSI/ON E)/H| DE/OSM. None of these editors, however, refers to any authority for this expression, which appears to me quaint and unnatural--"but if the dread of a paroxysm be at hand." I prefer H)/DH on the authority of many parallel passages, as for example--PLHSI/ON DE\ H)/DH TOU= FRENI/ZEIN O)/NTES, Galen, de loc. affect. iii.; E)NSTA/NTOS DE\ H)/DH TOU= SUMPTW/MATOS, P. Æ. iii. 5, in the chapter on epilepsy. Ermerins very properly restores it, in another passage of our author, where H(/DE had been substituted for it (Sympt. diut. morb. i. 9). Indeed H)/DH, in such cases, occurs frequently in the works of our author.

Moreover, in the margin of the celebrated Reiske's copy of Henisch's edition, there is found this emendation--H)/DH DE/OS. See G. Dindorf's Appendix to Kuhn's edition. The Latin translation of Crassus would agree very well with the reading I propose; while it is unsuitable to the text when DE/OS is admitted: "Quum vero accessio appropinquat."

div3.p: KATO/PIN KEKLASME/NAI, SKE/LEA CUGKEKAMME/NA· E)NANTI/WS GA\R I)GNU/H| KATO/PIN The common reading, KAKO/N TI, is obviously at fault. The present reading is adopted by Ermerins, only using I)GNU/H| in place of I)GNU/H. Still there is something unsatisfactory in the text. *)IGNU\S and I)GNU/H are applied, in strictness, to the back part of the thigh at its lower extremity. KA/MPTETAI.

It must be admitted, that although some improvement, the substituted terms are not quite suitable; as it can scarcely be said, that an internal disease is "driven outwards" by an external application.

A)KRATE/A DE\ KAI\ E)DWDH=S, KAI\ POIKI/LWN E)PIQUMI/A, KAI\ YUXROPOSI/H · KAI\ BOH=SAI ME/GA KAI\ E)N O)RGH=| KAI\ E)N PAIDIH=|. KAI\ KOU/RH|SI DE\ ME/XRI KAQA/RSIOS E)PIMHNI/WN TA/DE CUNH/QEA. XW/RH DE\ TI/KTEI *AI)/GUPTOS MA/LISTA, KAI\ GA\R E)S A)NAPNOH\N A)H\R CHRH\ KAI\ H( E)DWDH\ POIKI/LH.
p.note: The common reading is E)/H| instead of A)H\R; E)S instead of H(; and E)DWDH\N instead of E)DWDH/. Ermerins merely changes the E)/H| into H(/DE. I trust every candid and learned reader will admit, that I have greatly improved the meaning by the slight changes which I have ventured to make. From the translation of Crassus, it may be inferred that he had read A)H\R, or at least had seen the necessity of introducing it into the text: "Aer enim spirando siccus adducitur." I need scarcely add, that in the old Ionic, which our author affects, A)H\R is often put in the feminine gender. This was also the case in old Latin. See A. Gellius, xiii. 19.

*EU)= GE O(/LWS O( I)HTRO\S, H)DE\ O( DHMO/THS, EU)= GE E)PIKLH/SIOS TOU=DE TOU= PA/QEOS. W)KUTA/TOU KAKOU= E)STI OU)/NOMA·
p.note: The reading in all the MSS. is, W)\ KU/FWN OU(=--words which evidently have no meaning. Ermerins accordingly erases them, with the three following--KAKOU= E)STI OU)/NOMA-- altogether. This, I think, will generally be admitted to be too bold a procedure. The emendation suggested by Fabricius and Mattaire, and adopted by Wigan (namely, W)KUFO/NOU), is so plausible, and requires so little change of the characters, that I should have had no hesitation in adopting it, provided there were any authority for it; but this, I fear, is not the case. I have therefore ventured to substitute W)KUTA/TOU in place of it; and I am persuaded that, upon mature consideration, it will be approved of by every competent judge. I need scarcely remark, that it is of common occurrence in the works of the medical authorities, and that it is very applicable in this place.

LOIMW/DEES KAI\ SFO/DRA KAKOH/QEES E)C H(/PATOS
p.note: I must own, that I feel somewhat disposed to follow the suggestion of Wigan, and read H(/BHS: for it is well known that pestilential buboes occur principally in the groin (i. e. near the pubes), as is first noticed by Procopius (de Bello Persico, 22, 23). I am not aware, moreover, that any of the ancient authorities refer the pestilential buboes to the liver, but to the glands of the groin. See Agathias, Hist. v. and the other authorities quoted at P. ÆGINET. t. i. p. 232, Syd. Soc. Edit.

div3.p: *YUXH=S KATA/STASIS ,There has been much difference of opinion respecting these two words. I regard the construction as an Attic anacoluthon, of which many examples occur in our author's works, and in those of Ælian and Arrian, who were about his age. Ermerins mentions that Kün was disposed to regard them as belonging to the Glossema. This, I know, was suggested to him by the late Dr. Kerr, of Aberdeen, whose correspondence with Kün I saw at the time it took place, about thirty years ago. AI)/SQHSIS SU/MPASA KAQARH\, DIA/NOIA LEPTH\, GNW/MH MANTIKH/. PROGIGNW/SKOUSI ME\N OU)=N PRW/TISTA ME\N W(UTE/OISI TOU= BI/OU TH\N METALLAGH/N · E)/PEITA TOI=SI PAREOU=SI PROLE/GOUSI TA\ AU)=QIS E)SO/MENA · OI( DE\ AU)TE/OUS ME\N E)/SQ' O(/TE KAI\ A)LLOFA/SSEIN This conjectural emendation of Petit, which is adopted by Ermerins and Wigan, is an ingenious substitute for the common reading, A)/LLO FASI\, which evidently has no meaning. A still more simple emendation, however, would be, A)/LLO FA/SQAI-- that is to say, the spectators "fancy that they speak strange, i. e. incoherent." See Liddel and Scott's Lexicon under A)/LLOS, for this meaning of the word. DOKE/OUSI· TH=| A)POBA/SI DE\ TW=N EI)RHME/NWN QWU+MA/ZOUSI W(/NQRWPOI. METECE/TEROI DE\ KAI\ PROSLALE/OUSI TW=N KATOIXOME/NWN TISI\, TA/XA ME\N PAREO/NTAS O(REU=NTES AU)TOI\ MOU=NOI, U(PO\ LEPTH=S KAI\ KAQARH=S AI)SQH/SIOS, TA/XA D' AU)TW=N TH=S YUXH=S PROGGINWSKOU/SHS, KAI\ DIHGEUME/NHS TOU\S A)/NDRAS OI(=SI CUNE/SONTAI . PRO/SQEN ME\N GA\R E)N TOI=SI U(GROI=SI

p.foreign: W(S E)N I)LU/I+ E)/NHN KAI\ ZO/FW|.
p.note: Ermerins does not hesitate to expunge the word U(GROI=SIN altogether; but this seems to me an unwarrantable liberty. By the addition of one short word, W(S, and a little transposition, I flatter myself that I have greatly improved the text. Petit proposes to read I)LUW/DESI U(GROI=SI, but without referring to any medical authority for such an expression. In illustration of the general meaning of this sentence, see an important passage on the Pneuma, below. Therap. I. i.

div3.p: *NEFROI\, TH\N ME\N TOU= SW/MATOS I)DE/HN, OU) KA/RTA E)PI/KAIROI E)S KI/NDUNON, H)\N KAI/ TI PA/QWSI O)CE/WS. A)DENW/DEES GA\R TH\N FU/SIN, E)S DE\ O)/LEQRON EU)H/QEES·It appears to me that all the translators have misunderstood the meaning of these words, E)S DE\ O)/LEQRON EU)H/QEES, which Henisch and Boerhaave translate, "ad mortem vero inferendam ben・habiles sunt:" Wigan and Ermerins,--"ægrum tamen facile interimunt." Moffat rather oddly,--"well calculated for bearing an attack." Now the literal meaning of the words obviously is, "they are innocent as regards death;" which surely can imply nothing but that the affections of the kidneys are not naturally deadly. (See Liddel and Scott's Lexicon under the word.) In fact, whoever will read the context carefully must see that this meaning is the only one in accordance with it, and with what is said below, namely, that the majority of cases are not fatal. Ermerins, in this instance, vitiates the text by meddling with it, and substituting GA\R for DE\ after E)PI/KAIRON. E)PI/KAIRON DE\ AU)TE/WN TO\ E)/RGON, H(/ TE DIA/KRISIS TW=N OU)/RWN A)PO\ TOU= AI(/MATOS KAI\ H( A)PO/KRISIS.

p.foreign: *)EPE/XEI DE\ TH/NDE H)\ LI/QOS, H)\ E)GGIGNOME/NH FLEGMONH\, H)\ AI(MA/LWY, H)/ TI TOIO/NDE · EU)=TE E)K CUMPAQI/HS ME\N TH=S DIA\ TH\N I)DE/HN TOU= SW/MATOS KAKO\N GI/GNETAI OU)DE\N, H( DE\ E)PI/SXESIS TW=N OU)/RWN PA/NTA TA\ DEINA\ PRH/SSEI.
p.note: Here, again, nearly all the translators and editors have misunderstood the meaning of the passage from not perceiving that SW/MATOS is here applied not to the whole body, but to the organ or part of the body of which the author is treating, namely, the kidneys. It would be superfluous to multiply references to passages in which Aretæus applies SW=MA to a particular part of the body. See Morb. Diut. i. 10; Curat. Morb. Diut. i. 13; also Galen, De Locis Affectis, i.9. Indeed Aristotle applies it expressly to the kidneys, in the sense of the fleshy part of the organ, or viscus, H. A. i. 17, 15. The meaning of the passage in question, therefore, evidently is, that "no mischief from sympathy arises in this case, owing to the peculiar nature of the affected viscus itself, but the retention of the urine produces most horrible mischief." Wigan translates the passage thus, -- "reliqui corporis species, nullo affectus ex consensu, perturbatur." Boerhaave thus:--"quandoquidem ex consensu affectionis ob formam corporis provenientis nulla creatur offensio;" and Ermerins thus: "quo facto nullum quidem malum oritur propter cæterarum partium cum renis subitantia consensum." Of these translations that of Ermerins approaches nearest to the true import of the passage. The other two have no distinct meaning.

E)PI\ GUNAIKW=N ME\N GA\R AU)TE/WN KAI\ U(STE/RWN FLEGMONH\ A)NAPIE/ZEI, In all the MSS. the common reading is FLEGMONA\S, from which no suitable meaning can be elicited. Ermerins introduces many changes; thus he reads,--AU)TE/HN KAI\ U(STE/RH FLEGMH/NASA\ A)\N PIE/ZEI; and, in the next clause he erases TO\ EU)QU\. By merely changing FLEGMONA\S into -H\, I am persuaded that a legitimate reading is obtained. *)ANAPIE/ZW is a Hippocratic term. Art. 807, ed. Föes. It is to be borne in mind that the FLEGMONH\ of the ancients was a Phlegmon rather than an inflammation; i.e. it was O)/GKOS O)DUNHRO/S. See Föes, Œc. Hipp. E)P' A)NDRW=N DE\, TO\ E)/SXATON, TO\ EU)QU\, TO\ PARA/MHKE S E)/NTERON. div3.p:
*)\HN ZO/FOS TA\S O)/YIAS SXH=|, KAI\ DI=NOS A)MFI\ TH\N KEFALH\N E(LI/SSHTAI, KAI\ W)=TA BOMBE/H| O(/KWS *R(EO/NTWN KANAXHDO\N POTAMW=N, H)\ OI(=ON A)/NEMOS I(STI/OISI E)GKUBERNH=,
This word can scarcely be the right reading; but it is difficult to find a proper substitute for it. Were I disposed to bold attempts at emendation, I should propose to substitute E)MBRE/METAI in place of it; for, considering how fond our author is of Homeric diction, nothing seems so natural as to suppose that he had in mind the celebrated passage in the Iliad,--
------ A)NE/MOIO DE\ DEINO\S A)H/THS *(ISTI/W| E)MBRE/METAI (XV. 627).
Wigan suggests E)GKURKANE/H| or E)GKUKANE/H|; but these words are at least as objectionable as the one they are intended to supply a substitute for. In the MS. in the British Museum, we read EU)ERGE/INHI/+: and this, perhaps, is the true reading. EU)=TE E)PI\ ME\N CANQH=| XOLH=|, MANI/AI GI/GNONTAI· E)PI\ DE\ TOI=SI ME/LASI, MELAGXOLI/H · E)PI\ DE\ TW=| FLE/GMATI, H( E)PILHYI/H. PASW=N GA\R H(/DE NOU/SWN TROPH/.
p.note: Ermerins finds great difficulty in explaining the exact meaning of the last sentence. He does not seem to have adverted that our author had in view 75, 76, 77, 78, 79, 80, of the seventh section of the Aphorisms of Hippocrates. See the Commentary of Galen, and the English edition, Syd. Soc. Ed. t. ii. p.773. I must say, however, that TW=NDE seems wanting in this place.

p.note: I flatter myself that every person who is familiar with the metaphysics of the ancients, will admit that I have improved this sentence by changing H(/DE into H)DE/. Ermerins, not recognising the difference between the GNW/MH and the NOU=S, expunges TOU= NOU= from the text. On the distinction between these portions or powers of the mind, see Aristotle de Anima, iii. 10, etc.; Metaphysica, pluries.

div3.p: EU)MAQE/SI A)STRONOMI/H A)DI/DAKTOS,Though I have not meddled with the text, I am much inclined to think that the true reading would be A)UTODI/DAKTOS. It occurs in Æschylus, Agamem. 964. By the way, the example referred to by the Oxford lexicographers, to prove that A)DI/DAKTOS is sometimes used synonymously with AU)TODI/DAKTOS (namely, Lucian, Hist. Conscr. 34), is not in point here. We cannot say that "astronomy" is untaught, in the same sense that we can say that "political sagacity" is so. div3.p: *)\HN E(/LKOS E)C A)POSTA/SIOS E)N TW=| PNEU/MONI GE/NHTAI, H)\ E)K BHXO\S XRONI/HS, H)\ A)NAGWGH=S AI(/MATOS, KAI\ A)NABH/SSH| PU=ON, PU/H, Ermerins does not appear to me to be warranted in substituting FQO/H for PU/H, contrary to the authority of all the MSS. Moreover, it seems to be excluded from this place by the terms in which our author applies FQO/H to a particular state of the diseased parts-- A)LLA\ FQO/HN METALAMBA/NEI; i.e. "but the disease assumes the peculiar name of Phthoe." He is right, however, in following the suggestion of Petit, and substituting E(/LKOS for E)NTO\S at the commencement. KAI\ FQI/SIS KIKLH/SKETAI· H)\N DE\ QW/RHC H)\ PLEURO\N E)MPUH/SH|, E)PANA/GHTAI

DE\ DIA\ TOU= PNEU/MONOS, E)MPU/H H(/DE TOU)/NOMA.I am not aware that the term E)MPU/H occurs elsewhere. Hippocrates and Galen, I believe, universally use the substantive E)MPU/HMA, or the adjective E)/MPUOI- - the latter being their more common practice. H)\N DE\ E)PI\ TOI=SI KAI\ O( PNEU/MWN E(/LKOS I(/SXH|, A)NABRWQEI\S U(PO\ TOU= DIENEXQE/NTOS PU/OU, TOU)/NOMA OU)KE/TI E)MPU/H, A)LLA\ FQO/HN METALAMBA/NEI· CU/NESTI DE\ KAI\ PU=R CUNEXE\S, W(S MH\ DOKE/EIN,At first I was inclined to adopt the alteration of Ermerins, who substitutes MOI for MH\; but, after reading Cælius Aurelianus's description of Phthisis, I was convinced that MH\ is the preferable reading. The words of Aurelianus are: "Sequitur autem ægrotantes febricula latens," etc. LH=GON ME\N OU)/KOTE, LH=QON DE\ DI' H(ME/RHS I(DRW=TI KAI\ YU/CI TOU= SKH/NEOS. The translation of Crassus is most suitable to the context: "ut enim recessit," etc. Qu. A)NE/QH|? p.foreign: *FWNH\ BRAGXW/DHS· AU)XH\N U(POSKO/LIOS, *R(ADINO\S, OU)K EU)PARA/GWGOS· O(KOI=O/N TI CUNTETA ME/NOS· DA/KTULOI I)SXNOI\, TA\ DE\ A)/RQRA PAXE/A· O)STE/WN MOU/NWN H( I)DE/H· SMU/XONTAI GA\R KAI\ SA/RKES· O)/NUXES GRUPOI\ DAKTU/LWN, AI( KOILI/AI *R(USAI\ KAI\ PLATE/ES·
p.note: Ermerins, on his own authority, substitutes PLATE/AI; but the other reading is in accordance with a well-known Ionic usage. All the recent translators have fallen into the mistake of applying this passage to the abdomen; whereas a careful examination of the context will show that it is out of the question in this place. Crassus more correctly renders it thus: "Digitorum ventres rugosi et lati." *KOILI/AI in this place evidently applies to the pulps of the fingers.

p.note: This word is most probably a false reading. See Wigan and Ermerins. The latter reads *R(OIBOEIDE/A, one of Wigan's conjectural emendations. *(ROIKOEIDE/A and *R(EBOEIDE/A have also been suggested. If I thought myself warranted to make any change in the reading, it would be to adopt *R(AIBOEIDE/A. See Foes, Œc. Hipp.; and Galen, t. i. pp. 224, 246, ed. Daremberg.

p.foreign: TO\ KAKO\N A)POTEI/NETAI, PLH\N OU) PERAITE/RW E(NO\S E)/TEOS. H)/N TE GA\R TO\ METO/PWRON A)/RCH|, EI)S TO\ E)/AR H)\ TO\ QE/ROS A)POGI/GNONTAI· H)/N TE XEIMW\N, E)S TO\ METO/PWRON TELEUTW=SI TO\N BI/ON. KOTE\ KAI\ GE/RONTES A(LW=NAI *R(HI/+DIOI KAI\ A)PO/FRIKTOI A(LO/NTES, O(/SON BRAXEI/HS *R(OPH=S E)S EU)NH\N QANA/TOU XRE/OS·
p.note: I must say, I have never been able to satisfy myself with any interpretation of this passage which I have seen. Ermerins, indeed, very properly remarks, that in this sentence there is an indirect reference to a celebrated verse in the Oedipus Tyrannus of Sophocles; namely-- SMIKRA\ PALAIA\ SW/MAT' EU)NA/ZEI *R(OPH/--that is, "A slight inclination of the scale sets old persons asleep in death." But then A)PO/FRIKTOI A(LO/NTES create difficulty, inasmuch as the adjective never occurs elsewhere, as far as I am aware; and, moreover, I do not see how a shivering fit should necessarily occasion death. Instead of it, I would prefer A)PO/FRAKTOI; that is to say, with the meaning, "being seized with obstructed respiration." Still, however, there is a difficulty, inasmuch as it would not be easy to find any authority for this participle, although the verb be not uncommon. See Liddel and Scott. One might think of A)PO/PLHKTOI, which would be a very suitable term, as this is a very natural cause of sudden death in asthma.

PAIDI/OISI DE\, OU)K A)/HQES PA/GXU· OU) PA/NTH DE\ A)SFALE/S.

*CUMPA/NTWN O(MOU= PAQE/WN KAXECI/H TROPH/. A(/PASAI GA\R AI( NOU=SOI TH=SDE A)POTO/KOI. A)TA\R KAI\ H(/DE MOU/NH A)/NEUQEN TW=N A)/LLWN, FARMA/KWN E)PI/DOSIN E)/XOUSA POLLH\N, I)LUW/DEA KATA\ PRW/TISTA GI/GNETAI PA/QOS.
p.note: It appears to me most remarkable, that all the editors should have pronounced this passage thoroughly corrupt, and in particular that Ermerins should have gone the length of ejecting the greater part of the last clause altogether from the text. He reads thus: A)TA\R KAI\ H(/DE MOU/NH A)/NEUQEN TW=N A)/LLWN KATA\ PRW/TISTA GI/GNETAI PA/QOS. This is truly an heroical way of solving the Gordian knot! I flatter myself I have unravelled all the intricacies of the noose by a much more lenient process; namely, by merely shifting the accent of A)PO/TOKOI to the penult syllable, as suggested by Petit, and placing the comma [,] before I)LUW/DEA, instead of after it, as it stood in the former editions, and putting a comma after A)/LLWN, for which I have the authority of wigan. I do not hesitate to affirm, that FARMA/KWN and the other words connected with it are indispensable to the full signification of the passage, as any one may be convinced who will compare the account of Cachexia given by other authors. Thus, among the causes of Cachexia enumerated by Cælius Aurelianus, we find "item ex medicaminibus sæpissime potatis"--and "curatione mala medicantis." Tard. Pass. iii. 6. And much in the same style Celsus, treating of Cachexia, says: "Quod fere fit, cum longo morbo vitiata corpora, etiamsi illo vacant, refectionem tamen non recipiunt; aut cum malis medicamentis corpus affectum est." iii. 22.

p.note: Petit and Wigan suggest PNEU=MA instead of *R(EU=MA; but the former reading is defended by Ermerins. Though the general import of the passage be obvious, there is still something unsatisfactory in the language. Of course, reference is here made by our author to the saying of Heraclitus, as told by Diogenes Laertius. The philosopher having become dropsical, proposed a riddle to his physicians:--"If from rainy weather they could make dryness"--EI) DU/NAINTO E)C E(POMBRI/HS AU)XMO\N POIH=SAI.

TE/KMAR DE\, TW=N U(DA/TWN TW=N QERMW=N FU/SI AI( PHGAI/· A)POYUXQE/NTA GA\R, EI)S PWRWEIDE/A LI/QON PH/GNUTAI. div3.head: *KEF. D'. *PERI\ TW=N E)N *KU/STI.
div3.p: *TW=N E)N TH=| KU/STI NOU/SWN OU)DE\N EU)/HQES· TA\ ME\N O)CE/A FLEGMASI/H| KAI\ TRW/MASI, SPASMW=| KAI\ PURETOI=SI O)CE/SI KTEI/NONTA· E(/LKOS DE\ KAI\ A)POSTA/SIES, H)\ PARA/LUSIS, H)\ LI/QOS ME/GAS XRO/NIA ME\N, A)NALQH= DE/.I have followed the reading suggested by Wigan, and adopted by Ermerins. *XRO/NIA is wanting in all the MSS., but seems indispensable. OU)/TE GA\R QRU/PTETAI, H)\ PO/SI, H)\ FARMAKW|, H)\ A)MFIQRU/PTOITO, OU)/TE A)SINE/WS TE/MNETAI.I admit there is something equivocal in the text of this remarkable sentence; but I have not ventured to alter it. Wigan reads: *OU)/TE GA\R QRU/PTETAI H)/ PO/SI, H)/ FARMA/KW| A)MFIQRU/PTW|, K.T. L. Ermerins is still bolder in the liberties he uses: *OU)/TE GA\R O(/DE QRU/PTETAI PO/SI, OU)/TE A)SINE/WS TE/MNETAI. By the way, he might well have spared one word which he ejects, by reading PO/SI FARMA/KWN. Were I to meddle with the text at all, I should propose to read as follows: *OU)/TE GA\R QRU/PTETAI H)\ PO/SI FARMA/KWN, H)\ A)MFIQRU/PTOITO ( A)MFIQRU/PTETAI?) OU)/TE A)SINE/WS TE/MNETAI. I am willing to believe that the passage contains allusions to Lithotripsy, Lithotrity, and Lithotomy!! See PAULUS ÆGINETA , t. ii. p. 359, Syd. Soc. Ed. SHPEDW\N DE\ A)PO\ TOU= E(/LKEOS *R(E/EI OU)/TE AU)TE/H|SI FORHTH\, A)GRIAI/NEI YAU/SESI/ TE KAI\ FARMA/KOISI , KAI\ XALEPAI/NEI PWS KAI\ I)HTRI/H|· FLE/BES DE\ E)N U(STE/RH| E)S O)/GKON AI)/RONTAI CU\N PERITA/SESI TW=N PE/LAS· E)/STI DE\ PEPNUME/NOISI OU)K A)/SHMON TH=| A(FH=|.Ermerins, contrary to all authority, reads PEPNEUME/NH|SI, on the ground that, in ancient times, midwives alone were entrusted with the treatment of diseases of the female genital organs. This, however, was evidently not the case, as must be obvious to any one who has carefully read the Hippocratic treatise on this subject, and the other works contained in the Gynœcia. A)TA\R KAI\ XERSI\ MAI/HS A)TRE/MA EI)/SW QE/EI, H(SUXH= PIEZEUME/NH KAI\ XRIOME/NH PRO/SQEN TOI=SI U(STE/RHS MEILI/GMASI.I am not aware that this word occurs elsewhere in any medical author, as applied here. I am persuaded, then, that the proper reading is MALA/GMASI. On the malagmata or emollient plasters of the ancients, see P AULUS ÆGINETA, Syd. Soc. Edit. b. iii. pp. 576--581. They were much used in uterine diseases. See Ibid. b. iii. c. 68, etc.

div3.head: *KEF. IB'. *PERI\ *)ARQRI/TIDOS KAI\ *)ISXIA/DOS.
div3.p: *CUNO\S ME\N A(PA/NTWN TW=N A)/RQRWN PO/NOS H( A)RQRI=TIS· A)LLA\ PODW=N ME\N PODA/GRHN KALE/OMEN, I)SXIA/DA DE\ I)SXI/WN, XEIRA/GRHN DE\ XEIRW=N· H)/N GE ME\N SXE/DIOS H)=| E)PI/ TINI TW=N PROSKAI/RWN AI)TI/WN O( PO/NOS, H)\ KRU/BDHN DE\ MELETH/SH| POLLO\N XRO/NON H( NOU=SOS, EU)=TE E)PI\ PROFA/SI SMIKRH=| O( PO/NOS KAI\ H( NOU=SOS E)CH/FQH·I have ventured to read H)\ instead of H)\N, on my own authority; and have substituted TINI in place of TI, on the authority of Ermerins; but have rejected his alteration of MH\N into MH\, which I think spoils the passage; and have preferred ME\N, which has the authority of the Vatican MS. E)/STI DE\ A(PA/NTWN CULLH/BDHN TW=N NEU/RWN H( PA/QH, H)\N AU)CHQE\N TO\ KAKO\N A(/PASI E)PIFOITH=| · A)RXH\ DE\ NEU=RA TA\ DESMA\ TW=N A)/RQRWN, KAI\ O(KO/SA E)C O)STE/WN PE/FUKEKAI\ E)N O)STE/OISI E)MFU/NEI. QW/U+MA DE\ TOUTE/WN ME/GA. OU) PONE/EI ME\N GA\R QRI\C, *QRI\C here is used in an unusual sense. The literal translation of the expression would be, "They are not pained a hair," or "a hair's-breadth," i.e. in the slightest degree. Ermerins refers to Theocritus, Idyll. xiv. 9, for an example of this usage. See further Liddel and Seott's Lexicon, under the word. This usage of it appears very forced in the present instance, and I suspect the reading to be corrupt. OU)D' A)\N TE/MNH| TIS H)\ QLI/BH|· H)\N DE\ E)C E(WUTE/WN PONH=|, OU)DE\ E(/TERON A)LGE/EI TOU=DE DUNATW/TERON, OU) SIDHRA\ SFI/GGONTA, OU) DESMA\, OU) TITRW=SKON CI/FOS, OU) KAI=ON PU=R. KAI\ GA\R KAI\ TAU=TA E)PANAIROU=NTAI W(S MEZO/NWN PO/NWN A)/KEA·

KAI\ H)\N TA/MH| TIS AU)TA\ PONEU=NTA, A)MAUROU=TAI O( TH=S TOMH=S PO/NOS SMIKRO\S U(PO\ TOU= ME/ZONOS · H)\N DE\ O(/DE KRATE/H|, H(DONH\ SFE/AS LA/ZUTAI E)PILH/QOUSA TW=N PA/ROS· PA/SXOUSI DE\ TOU=TO O)DO/NTES KAI\ O)STE/A.

*AI)TI/HN DE\ A)TREKE/A ME\N I)/SASI MOU=NOI QEOI\, E)OIKUI=AN DE\ KAI\ A)/NQRWPOI · E)/STI DE\ W(S E)/POS EI)PEI=N TOIO/NDE. TO\ ME\N KA/RTA PUKNO\N A)NAI/SQH TON YAU/SIOS KAI\ TRW/SIOS, TH=|DE KAI\ A)/PONON YAU/SI KAI\ TRW/SI. A)/LGOS GA\R TRHXEI/A| E)N AI)SQH/SI, TO\ DE\ PUKINO\N A)TRH/XUN TON · DIA\ TO/DE KAI\ A)/PONON· TO\ DE\ A)RAIO\N, EU)AISQH TO\N , KAI\ TRHXU/NETAI TRW/MATI. A)LL' E)PEI\ KAI\ TA\ PUKNA\ ZH=| E)MFU/TW| QE/RMH|, KAI\ AI)/SQETAI TH=|DE TH=| QE/RMH|· EI) ME\N OU)SIW/DHS H( DRW=SA AI)TI/H E)/OI, OI(=ON H) MA/XAIRA H)\ LI/QOS, TO\ OU)SIW=DES TOU= PA/SXONTOS OU)K A)LGE/EI· PUKNO\N GA\R TH\N FUH/N. H)\N DE\ TH=S E)MFU/TOU QE/RMHS DUSKRASI/H LA/BHTAI, AI)SQH/SIOS GI/GNETAI TROPH/. TOU=TO W)=N E)C E(WUTE/HS PONE/EI H( QE/RMH, E)K TH=S KAT' AI)/SQHSIN E)/SWQEN E)GEI/RETAI W)/SIOS. FU/SIOS DE\ TH=S E)S ME/ZW, H)\ PERIOUSI/HS, TA\ A)/LGEA.

*)EGXRI/MPTETAI DE\ H( A)RQRI=TIS A)/LLOTE E)S A)/LLA A)/RQRA, TOI=S ME\N E)S I)SXI/A, KAI\ TA\ POLLA\ TH=|DE E)PIMI/MNEI GUIO\S,In the common editions, and I believe in all the MSS., we find GU/I+OS, which is obviously at fault, at least as regards accentuation. Ermerins, accordingly, does not hesitate to expunge the term altogether. But to GUIO\S I can see no objection. It is thus explained in the Lexicon of Hesychius: *GUIO\S, XWLO\S, NOSW/DHS, PHRW/DHS. This is sufficient authority for the word, although it is not in common use. See also Liddel and Scott's Lexicon, under the term. There are other difficulties in the remaining part of the sentence, which I cannot bring myself to remove by expunging all the difficult words, after the example of Ermerins. A(/SSA TE ME/LEA/ KOTE MIKRO\N, EU)=TE OU)DE\ E)PI\ TA\ SMIKRA\ FOITH=|, PO/DAS TE KAI\ XEI=RAS. H)\N GA\R MEIZO/NWN LA/BHTAI MELE/WN XWRH=SAI TH\N NOU=SON DUNAME/NWN, OU)X U(PERBAI/NEI TA\ O)/RGANA· H)\N DE\ A)PO\ TOU= SMIKROU= A)/RCHTAI, E)/STI EU)H/QHS KAI\ A)DO/KHTOS H( EI)SBOLH/. I)SXIA/DOS ME\N A)PO\ MHROU=KATO/PIN, H)\ I)GNU/OS, H)\

KNH/MHS, H( A)RXH/. A)/LLOTE DE\ E)PI\ TH=| KOTU/LH| TO\ A)/LGHMA FAI/NETAI, AU)=QIS E)S GLOUTO\N H)\ O)SFU\N O)KE/LLEI, KAI\ PA/NTA MA=LLO/N E)STIN H)\ DO/KHSIS I)SXI/OU. A)TA\R KAI\ TA\ A)/RQRA W(=DE/ PWS A)/RXETAI · TOU= PODO\S TO\N ME/GAN DA/KTULON A\LGE/EI, AU)=QIS TH\N E)PIPRO/SW PTE/RNHN, H(=| POTE STHRIZO/MEQA· E)/PEITA E)S TO\ KOI=LON H(=KE· TO\ DE\ SFURO\N E)CW|/DHSE U(/STATON. PRO/FASIN DE\ AI)TIW=NTAI A)NAI/TION, OI( ME\N KRHPI=DOS KAINH=S TRI/BON, OI( DE\ MAKRH\N PERI/ODON · A)/LLOS DE\ PLHGH\N H)\ PA/THMA· OU)DEI\S DE\ FRA/SEI TH\N OI)/KOQEN OU)=SAN, A)TA\R KAI\ A)KOU/SASI TOI=SI PA/SXOUSI TO\ A)TREKE\S E)/DOCE A)/PISTON· DIA\ TO/DE E)S A)NH/KESTON E)TRA/PH, O(/TIPER TH=|SI A)RXH=|SI O(KO/TE A)SQENESTA/TH E)STI\ H( NOU=SOS, O( I)HTRO\S OU)K E)NI/STATAI· H)\N DE\ XRO/NW| KRATUNQH=|, A)NO/NHTOS H( MELE/TH. TISI\ ME\N OU)=N E)S PODW=N A)/RQRA MI/MNEI ME/SFI QANA/TOU, TISI\ DE\ NE/METAI E)S TH\N TOU= PANTO\S SKH/NEOS PERI/ODON · TA\ POLLA\ DE\ A)PO\ TW=N PODW=N E)S XEI=RAS H)/I+CE. OU) GA\R MEGA/LA TA\ O(/RIA TH=| NOU/SW| XEIRW=N TE KAI\ PODW=N, O(/TI A)/MFW O(MOFUE/A, I)SXNA\ KAI\ A)/SARKA KAI\ E)GGUTA/TW TOU= E)/CW YU/XEOS· A)PWTA/TW DE\ TOU= E)/SW QA/LPEOS. AU)=QIS A)GKW\N KAI\ GO/NU· E)PI\ DE\ TOI=SI KOTU/LAI, PERI/STROFOS H(/DE META/BASIS E)S NW/TOU MU/AS KAI\ QW/RHKOS. Though the text be not in quite a satisfactory state, I prefer leaving it as it stands, rather than adopt the slashing alterations made in it by Ermerins. He reads the last clause thus: E)PI\ DE\ TOI=SI KOTU/LH|SI PERI/STROFOS· H)/DH META/BASIS E)S NW/TOU MU/AS KAI\ QW/RHKOS. Wigan merely proposes to read PERI/STROFOI H)DE\. A)/PISTON EI)S O(/SON E(/RPEI TO\ KAKO/N. SPO/NDULOI A)LGE/OUSI *R(A/XEO/S TE KAI\ AU)XE/NOS, KAI\ E)S A)/KRON E)REI/DEI TOU= I(EROU= O)STE/OU· KAI\ CUMPA/NTWN TOU= BOUBW=NOS KAI\ I)DI/H| H( E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH.
The following most extraordinary reading occurs in all the MSS.: KAI\ CUMPA/NTW N TE O( BOU=S, O)/NOS, KAI\ H( I)DE/H ( I)DI/H, Harl.) E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH; which words, in the old translation of Crassus, are rendered literally,--"Simulque omnium bos, asinus, et proprius cujusque dolor." What can an ox or an ass have to do with an attack of Schiatica?
Fortunately the Askew MS. belonging to the Medical Society of London, has guided me to what I do not hesitate to pronounce the true reading. In the margin of this MS., opposite the corrupted words, stand the following characters, apparently in the handwriting of the amanuensis:--
I)/SBOUBW=N
That is to say, I)/SWS, BOUBW=NOS. Now, that "pain of the groin" is a constant attendant of Schiatica, every practical physician is well aware; and, in fact, this is one of the symptoms enumerated in the best descriptions of the disease furnished by the ancient authorities. For example, Cælius Aurelianus has the following words in his chapter on Schiatica and Lumbago: "Et primo, in vertebra dolor sentitur, dehinc partis suæ penetrans loca usque ad mediam natem, ac superius ad inguen," etc. Tard. Pass. v. 1. In like manner, Aetius describes the symptoms as follows: POLLOI=S DE\ H( O)DU/NH E)REI/DETAI KATA\ TOU= BOUBW=NOS O(/TE KAI\ H( KU/STIS METALAMBA/NOUSA TH=S DUSKOLI/AS DUSOURI/AN E)PIFE/REI. Ex. MS. in Bibl. Bodl. Cod. Canon. Græc. cix.
In a word, the substitution of TOU= BOUBW=NOS for TE O( BOU=S, O)/NOS, is so natural, that I feel persuaded no reasonable critic will demur to adopt it. Some other slight changes, however, are requisite in this passage, which might be effected in two or three different ways. I subjoin a few of my own attempts, some of which may perhaps be thought superior to the reading I have adopted:--
1. KAI\ CUMPA/NTWN TOU= BOUBW=NOS [ TO/PWN] KAI\ H( I)DI/H E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH.
2. KAI\ CUMPA/NTWN TE BOUBW=NOS KAI\ I)DI/H| H( E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH.
3. KAI\ CU/MPANTOS TOU= BOUBW=NOS KAI\ H( I)DI/H| E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH.
4. KAI\ E)S CU/MPANTW=N TOU= BOUBW=NOS KAI\ I)DI/H E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH.
Every one of these specimens of an emended text brings out an appropriate meaning; namely, that "there is a general pain of the whole inguinal region, and a particular pain of every part situated therein."
I have now to state briefly the emendations of this passage proposed by preceding editors and commentators. Wigan, while he retains the vitiated reading of the MSS., adds in a note at the end: "Cert legendum O(MOU= PO/NOS. Ita eleganter vehementia doloris describitur, Vertebrœ et dolore torquentur, qui omnes œqu・occupare prœcipitur, et alium etiam insuper sentiunt, qui singulis suus et proprius videtur." Petit's emendation is very nearly the same: KAI\ CUMPA/NTWN TE O(MOU= PO/NOS, KAI\ H( I)DI/H E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH. It is adopted by Ermerins with a slight change: KAI\ CUMPA/NTWN TE O(MOU= PO/NOS KAI\ I)DI/H| E(KA/STOU O)DU/NH.

H)\N GA\R PRO\S TH\N AU)GH\N A)GRIAI/NWSI , KAI\ O(RE/WSI TA\ MH\ O)/NTA, KAI\ TA\ MH\ U(PEO/NTA FANTA/ZWNTAI, H)\ A)NQ' E(TE/RWN E(/TERA GIGNW/SKWSI , H)\ CE/NA I)NDA/LMA TA PROBA/LLWNTAI, KAI\ TO\ CU/NOLON TH\N AU)GH\N H)\ TA\ E)N AU)GH=| DEDI/TTWNTAI, ZO/FON AI(RE/ESQAI XRH/· H)\N DE\ MH\, TOU)NANTI/ON.Ermerins, following in the wake of Wigan, suppresses, first, the clause KAI\ O(RE/WSI TA\ MH\ O)/NTA; and, second, H)\ A)NQ' E(TE/RWN E(/TERA GIGNW/SKWSI , as being mere glosses on the clauses connected with them. I must say, decidedly, that I cannot approve of such editorial practices. If the works of the ancient authorities are to be thus modified agreeably to the tastes and caprices of modern editors, we shall by-and-bye be at a loss to know what is ancient and what modern, in works reputed to be of olden date. And, moreover, although the clauses in question may not be indispensable to the meaning, I cannot but think that they give effect to the other clauses in this passage. But the emendation substituted by Ermerins seems preferable, being founded on the rules laid down by Hippocrates in his work, "On Aliment in Acute Diseases."--See Syd. Soc. Edit. t. i. QUMO/N TE GA\R PRHO+/NONTAI MALQA/CI FRENW=N, KAI\ E)C E(WUTE/WN E)S DU/NAMIN TRE/FONTAI· A)TA\R H)DE\ E(WUTE/OISI E)MPNE/OUSI E)S H(DONH/N.The last clause of this sentence seems decidedly to be corrupt. How much is it to be lamented that this eulogium on wine, which appears to be so judicious and so eloquent, should be marred, in so far, by the corruptions of the text! Petit suggests E(WUTE/OUS E)MPLE/OUSI, which would be an improvement of the sense, in my opinion; but it is rejected by Ermerins.

*)\HN DE\ TRO/MOS XEIRW=N KAI\ KEFALH=S E)/H|, KASTO/RION PIPI/SKEIN DRAXMH=S O(LKH=S H(/MISU CU\N MELIKRH/ TOU KUA/QOIS TRISI\ E)S H(ME/RAS PLEU=NAS· H)\N DE\ MH\ PI/NH| TO/DE, E)NTH/KEIN CUMFO/RW| E)LAI/OU,The reading in most of the MSS., E)/KTEUCIN CUMFORH=S CU\N E)LAI/W|, has evidently no meaning. Petit mentions, that on the margin of a certain good MS. he found E)S E)/KFEUCIN, which certainly gives a passable meaning, with little violence to the text. Wigan suggests CUMFE/ROI or CU/MFERON E(YEI=N. Ermerins creates a reading to suit his own faney--E)S TE/GCIN CU/MFERON. Such a change appears to me utterly inadmissible as being both violent and introducing a meaning not suitable to the place. It will be seen that I have tried my skill in emending this passage--with what success, judicent eruditi. E)/NQA PH/GANON E)NEZE/SQH KUA/QOIS TRISI\, TO\ DE\ DIPLO/ON

TA/DE GA\R MA/LISTA PA/SXEITE DEINA\ KAI\ TEI/NEI.The common reading, TEI/NEI, Ermerins alters to KTEI/NEI on the authority of a Parisian MS. Maittaire holds TEI/NEI to be an example of an active verb taken in a passive signification (ed. Wigan). We would render it by tenduntur, cntenduntur, "we are on the stretch." Similar examples are in Latin; as, "prora avertit." Virg. Æn. i. 104. MA/LISTA ME\N W)=N AU)TH=MAR FLE/BA TA/MNEIN · H)\N DE\ A)PO\ PLH/SIOS SI/TWN KAI\ POTW=N E)/H|, E)P' A)SITI/HS MI/HN H(ME/RHN FULA/CANTA, A)FAIRE/EIN A)P' A)GKW=NOS TH=S E)N TW=| KOI/LW| FLEBO\S, TOU= KAT' I)/CIN TH=|SI E(TE/RH|SI PLEURH=|SI· The common reading is TOU= MH\; but it is clear that the negative cannot stand with the words that follow: TH=SI E(TE/RH|SI PLEURH=|SI. Ermerins gets over the difficulty by suppressing the last three words. I have effected the same purpose by merely suppressing the negative MH/. I have adopted his reading of A)P' in place of U(/P', in the same sentence. KRE/SSON GA\R A)PWTA/TW A)/GEIN. TO\ DE\ PLH=QOS MH\ ME/XRI LEIPOQUMI/HS·

PERIPNEUMONI/HN GA\R E)PIFOITH=SAI KI/NDUNOS, H)\N TO\ SW=MA E)PIYUXQE\N TH\N YUXH\N E)KLEI/PH|.Though I have not ventured to alter the text, I cannot but think that we ought to read H( YUXH/. For in LEIPOQUMI/A and LEIPOYUXI/A, it surely is thought that the spirit for a time leaves the body--not that the body leaves the spirit. In the Iliad, the act of swooning is thus described: *TO\N D' E)/LIPE YUXH\ (v. 696); upon which words the scholion is, OU)=TOS DE\ E)LEIPOYU/XHSEN. I)/SXHTAI DE\ TO\ AI(=MA, E)S TA)NANTI/A E)K PROSAGWGH=S H( METABOLH/· KAI\ MHDE\N A)/GAN. FILO/STROFA GA\R TA/DE KAI\ KAKOH/QEA. XRH\ DE\ SARKOU=N H)/DH TO\N A)/NQRWPON KAI\ TA\S W)TEILA\S E)S TO\ PIHRO\N A)/GEIN, AI)W/RH|S, H)\ TRI/YESI MALQAKH=|SI, PERIO/DOISI , QUMHDI/H|SI, TROFH=| POIKI/LH| KAI\ CUNH/QEI+. Ermerins boldly changes PIHRO\N to STEREO\N, a word bearing no resemblance whatever to the one in the text. I prefer leaving matters as they are, although I must say, I have a strong wish to expunge the words TA\S W)TEILA\S altogether, as being quite out of place. Our author seems to say, that in hæmoptysis it is a good thing to put flesh and fat on the patient. Of course, PIHRO\S is intended as the Ionic of PIARO/S. Wigan uses TO\N PW=RON instead of TO\ PIHRO\N; but I am not aware that there is any authority for this term being applied to a cicatrix in the fleshy parts.

div3.p: *)EN H(/PATI TOU= AI(/MATOS H( GE/NNA, KAI\ E)S TO\ PA=N E)/NQEN H( TOU=DE A)/FESIS.This reading, instead of the common one, TOU= A)FEXH/, was first suggested by Petit. KAI\ TO\ CU/MPAN H(=PAR O(KOI=ON AI(/MATOS PA/GOS. O)CU/TATAI W)=N AI( TH=|DE FLEGMONAI/. E)GKE/ETAI GA\R TW=| XWRI/W| TW=|DE H( TROFH/. H)\N ME\N E(TE/RWQI/ PH FLEGMONH\ SUSTH=|, OU) KA/RTA GI/GNETAI O)CE/H· ZE/EI GA\R H( TOU= AI(/MATOS E)PIRROH/. The common reading is NE/EI, which Ermerins makes NE/H, having adopted it from Bernard, ad Nonnum, i. p. 52. It occurs also in Cod. Harley. But neither the one nor the other furnishes any meaning suitable to the place. To my mind, there can be no doubt that the proper reading is ZE/EI, which occurs in Alexander's description of inflammation of the liver, as follows:--*(/OTI ME\N W(/SPER A(/PASA FLEGMONH\ E)K ZE/ONTOS AI(/MATOS E)/XEI TH\N GE/NESIN, OU(/TW KAI\ H( E)N TW=| H(/PATI, K. T.L. (vi. 19). The meaning, then, obviously is, that in inflammations of other parts, the blood, which is the pabulum of the inflammation, has to come from another place to the part inflamed; whereas in inflammations of the liver, the blood is inflamed in the place where it is originally formed. E)PI\

H)\N ME\N OU)=N A)/PUROIThe common reading, A)/POROI, is obviously at fault. Wigan, on good MS. authority, reads A)/PUROI, which is adopted by Ermerins. Petit suggests A)/PUOI, which would be most suitable to the place, if it were supported by as good authority as the amendment of Wigan. It is found, indeed, in the Lexicon of Suidas; but I am not aware that it occurs elsewhere. div3.p: TA/MNEIN W)=N AU)TI/KA TO\N KENEW=NA,Wigan suggests A)GKW=NA, and Ermerins accordingly receives this term into his text. H)\N ME\N W)=N TW=N A)/NW TI LUPH=|, PRO/EISI GUNAIKHI/+WN E)/CW.All the commentators are agreed that the common reading, PROSIO/NTWN, cannot stand. I have followed Ermerins in adopting a conjectural emendation suggested by Petit in part. W(=N DE\ KATA\ STO/MATI A)\N EI)/H, O)PI/SW XA/ZETAI H)DE\ A)/NW· I)/H| D' A)/N POTE KAI\ E)/NQA KAI\ E)/NQA POTI\ SPLH=NA KAI\ H(=PAR· CUNDIDOI= DE\ TA\ U(ME/NIA E)S A)PO/STASIN KAI\ CUNAGWGH\N, O(/KWS NHO\S LAI/FEA.

*PA/SXEI DE\ TA/DE KAI\ U(PO\ FLEGMASI/HS . KAI\ GA\R PROPETESTE/RH TW=| PA/QEI+ KAI\ TW=| O)/GKW| TOU= AU)XE/NOS GI/GNETAI· H( GA\R KATA\ PUQME/NA FLEGMASI/H A)/NW *R(E/PEI, H)\N ME\N E)S PO/DAS, E)/CW.It must be admitted, that the text is not in a satisfactory state; and yet I have not seen any emendation which I can think of adopting. For PA/QEI+, Ermerins reads BA/QEI+, which occurs in the margin of Henisch's edition; but I am not aware that this term is ever applied to any part of the uterus. The same objection applies to his use of TW\ PO/DE in the next sentence. Were I disposed to meddle with the text at all, I should substitute BA/REI+. It appears to me that, from the commencement of this paragraph down to TLH/MONAS, we have one of those long and complicated sentences in which Thucydides, Demosthenes, and other of the great writers of antiquity delighted. This style of composition is very different from the periodic style in which Roman, French, and English authors compose their works. Clarendon, Milton, and Cobbett are the best examples we have, in English, of the old Grecian style of writing in long sentences.--FLEBW=N TW=N E)P' A)GKW=NOS, METW/POU TH=S O)RQI/AS, SIKU/HS · TA\S DE\ A)FAIRE/SIAS MH\ ME/SFI LEIPOQUMI/HS POIE/ESQAI, PRO/KLHSIS GA\R TOU= PA/QEOS LEIPOQUMI/H · A)RTHRI/AS TA/MNEIN A(PA/SAS, TA/S TE W)/TWN PRO/SW TE KAI\ O)PI/SW· KAQA/RSIAS DE\ POIE/ESQAI E)COXE/AS TOUTE/WN PA/NTWN, TH=| I(ERH=| TW=| KAQARTHRI/W| KAI\ TH=S KEFALH=S TOI=SI A)/GOUSI FLE/GMA· POLLW=| DE\ DUNATW/TERA E)/STW FA/RMAKA · FE/REI GA\R H( E(/CIS TW=NDE TOU\S PO/NOUS· EU)QUMI/H DE\ KAI\ EU)ELPISTI/H TI/QHSI TOU\S NOSE/ONTAS TLH/MONAS. div3.p: SITI/WN KAI\ *R(AFANI/DWN POLLA/KIS.There can be little or no doubt that the words in the lacuna immediately adjoining SITI/WN, were E)/METOS A)PO/. On the popular modes of producing easy vomiting in ancient times, see PAULUS ÆGINETA, t. i, pp. 52--54. On the use of emetics in the cure of Arthritis and Schiatica, see further, Ibid. t. i. pp. 652--676, passim. E)/PEITA E)S TO\N E)LLE/BORON A)/GEIN. I cannot but think, however, that the more natural reading would be MH\; meaning, that the remedies in certain cases proved beneficial, and in others not.
